<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>The Audit Committee requires that it
approve in advance all audit and non-audit work performed by
PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP. On March 9, 2016, the Audit Committee approved
services to be performed by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP for the remainder of
fiscal year 2015 that are related to the audit of Kroger or involve the audit
itself. In 2007, the Audit Committee adopted an audit and non-audit service
pre-approval policy. Pursuant to the terms of that policy, the Committee will
annually pre-approve certain defined services that are expected to be provided
by the independent auditors. If it becomes appropriate during the year to engage
the independent accountant for additional services, the Audit Committee must
first approve the specific services before the independent accountant may
perform the additional work.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP has advised the
Audit Committee that neither the firm, nor any member of the firm, has any
financial interest, direct or indirect, in any capacity in Kroger or its
subsidiaries.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>The Board of Directors Recommends a
Vote <U>For</U> This Proposal.</FONT></B></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial>55</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Audit Committee Report</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Management of the Company is responsible
for the preparation and presentation of the Company&#146;s financial statements, the
Company&#146;s accounting and financial reporting principles and internal controls,
and procedures that are designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding
compliance with accounting standards and applicable laws and regulations. The
independent public accountants are responsible for auditing the Company&#146;s
financial statements and expressing opinions as to the financial statements&#146;
conformity with generally accepted accounting principles and the effectiveness
of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>In performing its functions, the Audit
Committee:</FONT></P>
<TABLE style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>Met separately with the
      Company&#146;s internal auditor and PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP with and</FONT>
      <FONT face=Arial size=2>without management present to discuss the results
      of the audits, their evaluation and management&#146;s</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>assessment of the effectiveness of Kroger&#146;s internal controls over
      financial reporting and the overall</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>quality
      of the Company&#146;s financial reporting;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>Met separately with the
      Company&#146;s Chief Financial Officer or the Company&#146;s General Counsel</FONT>
      <FONT face=Arial size=2>when needed;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>Met regularly in executive
      sessions;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>Reviewed and discussed with
      management the audited financial statements included in our</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>Annual Report;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>Discussed with
      PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP the matters required to be discussed under
      the</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>applicable requirements of the Public
      Company Accounting Oversight Board;</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>Received the written
      disclosures and the letter from PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP required by
      the</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>applicable requirements of the Public
      Accounting Oversight Board regarding the independent public</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>accountant&#146;s communication with the Audit Committee
      concerning independence and discussed</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>with
      them matters related to their independence; and</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Based upon the review and discussions
described in this report, the Audit Committee recommended to the Board of
Directors that the audited consolidated financial statements be included in the
Company&#146;s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended January 30, 2016, as
filed with the SEC.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>This report is submitted by the Audit
Committee.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>Ronald L. Sargent, Chair<BR>Anne
Gates<BR>Susan J. Kropf<BR>Susan M. Phillips<BR>Bobby S. Shackouls</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial>56</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Item No. 4 Shareholder
Proposal</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>We have been notified by nine
shareholders, the names and shareholdings of which will be furnished promptly to
any shareholder upon written or oral request to Kroger&#146;s Secretary at our
executive offices, that they intend to propose the following resolution at the
annual meeting:</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>The Kroger
Company<BR></FONT></B><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Human Rights Risk Assessment -
2016</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>&#147;RESOLVED, that shareholders of The Kroger
Co. (&#147;Kroger&#148;) urge the Board of Directors to report to shareholders, at
reasonable cost and omitting proprietary information, on Kroger&#146;s process for
identifying and analyzing potential and actual human rights risks of Kroger&#146;s
operations and supply chain (referred to herein as a &#147;human rights risk
assessment&#148;) addressing the following:</FONT></P>
<TABLE style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top width="99%"><FONT face=Arial>Human rights principles used to frame
      the assessment</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top width="99%"><FONT face=Arial>Frequency of assessment</FONT>
    <BR>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top width="99%"><FONT face=Arial>Methodology used to track and measure
      performance</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top width="99%"><FONT face=Arial>Nature and extent of
      consultation with relevant stakeholders in connection with the
      assessment</FONT> <BR>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top width="99%"><FONT face=Arial>How the results of the
      assessment are incorporated into company policies and decision
      making.</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>The report should be made available to
shareholders on Kroger&#146;s website no later than October 31, 2016.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Supporting Statement</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>As long-term shareholders, we favor
policies and practices that protect and enhance the value of our investments.
There is increasing recognition that company risks related to human rights
violations, such as litigation, reputational damage, and project delays and
disruptions, can adversely affect shareholder value.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Kroger, like many other companies, has
adopted a supplier code of conduct (See The Kroger Company Standard Vendor
Agreement) but has yet to publish a company-wide Human Rights Policy, addressing
human rights issues and a separate human rights code that applies to its
suppliers. Adoption of these principles would be an important first step in
effectively managing human rights risks. Companies must then assess risks to
shareholder value of human rights practices in their operations and supply
chains to translate principles into protective practices.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>The importance of human rights risk
assessment is reflected in the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and
Human Rights (the &#147;Ruggie Principles&#148;) approved by the UN Human Rights Council
in 2011. The Ruggie Principles urge that &#147;business enterprises should carry out
human rights due diligence... assessing actual and potential human rights
impacts, integrating and acting upon the findings, tracking responses, and
communicating how impacts are addressed.&#148; (http://www.business-humanrights.org/media/documents/ruggie/ruggie-guiding-principles-21-mar-2011.pdf)</FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Kroger&#146;s
business exposes it to significant human rights risks. As of year-end 2014,
Kroger operations, including supermarkets, convenience and jewelry stores, are
located in over 40 states. While over 90% of Kroger&#146;s business is food its
vendor Code of Conduct is based heavily on compliance with the law, and U.S.
agricultural workers are excluded from many labor laws that apply to other U.S.
workers. The company&#146;s supply chain is complex and global and violations of
human rights in Kroger&#146;s supply chain can lead to negative publicity, public
protests, and a loss of consumer confidence that can have a negative impact on
shareholder value.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>We urge shareholders to vote for this
proposal.&#148;</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial>57</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>The Board of Directors Recommends a
Vote <U>Against</U> This Proposal for the Following Reasons:</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Like the proponents, the Board also
recognizes the importance of ensuring that those seeking to do business with us
respect basic human rights. However, the Board opposes this proposal because we
are already working to ensure an ethical supply chain for the products sold in
our stores and we have a zero tolerance policy for human rights violations.
Furthermore, we regularly consider our policies and practices and we have
recently taken several important steps to drive into our supply chain greater
responsibility and accountability:</FONT></P>
<TABLE style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>In 2015, after consultation
      with a number of stakeholders, we updated our Vendor Code of
      Conduct</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>(the &#147;Code of Conduct&#148;), which is
      available at www.thekrogerco.com. The new Code of Conduct</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>makes it clear that our suppliers and their suppliers
      are expected to live up to our standards as set</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>forth in the Code of Conduct. To the extent they do not live up to
      such standards, we will not do</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>business
      with them.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>In 2015, we created a social
      responsibility center of excellence (the &#147;Center of Excellence&#148;) to</FONT>
      <FONT face=Arial size=2>schedule, review and monitor social responsibility
      audits, assess risks such as those described</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>above and develop a reporting structure that informs our business
      decisions. The Center of</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>Excellence is also
      tasked with recommending ways to continually improve social accountability
      in</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>our supply chain.</FONT>
<BR>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>In 2015, our annual
      sustainability report included a more in-depth report on our social
      responsibility</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>activities, which is
      available at sustainability.kroger.com.</FONT>
<BR>&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>Since 2012, we have more than
      doubled the number of social responsibility audits we have</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>conducted and we expect this program to continue to
      grow.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 30pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9675;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>This past year, our work
      revealed several facility failures. Many of these facilities have
      significantly improved through corrective action plans, but we are no
      longer doing business with a few.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>In 2016, we made the Kroger
      Social Responsibility Audit Checklist (the &#147;Audit Checklist&#148;)
      available</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>online. The Audit Checklist is
      required for Kroger suppliers that our social responsibility team</FONT>
      <FONT face=Arial size=2>identifies as higher risk due to variables such as
      country, product and/or industry.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 30pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9675;</FONT></TD>
    <TD VALIGN="TOP" WIDTH="99%" STYLE="text-align: left"><FONT face=Arial>In commodities and/or regions
      that are higher risk, like farmed shrimp in Thailand, we not only request
      supplier audits but also work with third party environmental and social
      certification programs to further eliminate risk in the supply
      chain.<BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse; TEXT-ALIGN: justify" cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD style="PADDING-RIGHT: 8pt; PADDING-LEFT: 15pt" vAlign=top width="1%"><FONT style="FONT-SIZE: 9.5pt">&#9679;</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top width="99%"><FONT face=Arial>In 2016, Kroger will also
      conduct a third party review of commodities in our supply chain to
      further</FONT> <FONT face=Arial size=2>assess both environmental and
      social risks.</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>We expect our program to continue to
evolve and develop based on input from suppliers, customers, government,
non-governmental organizations and developments within the industry. We believe
that these efforts represent significant and positive steps forward for our
Company&#146;s social responsibility program.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Kroger is already actively implementing,
monitoring, and continually improving our policies and practices, addressing a
number of the areas discussed by the proponent. We believe that preparation of
an additional report would not be an efficient use of our shareholders&#146;
resources. We urge you to vote </FONT><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>AGAINST</FONT></B><FONT face=Arial size=2> this proposal.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Item No. 5 Shareholder
Proposal</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>We have been notified by one shareholder,
the name and shareholdings of which will be furnished promptly to any
shareholder upon written or oral request to Kroger&#146;s Secretary at our executive
offices, that it intends to propose the following resolution at the annual
meeting:</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial>58</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Shareholder Proposal<BR>Recyclability
of Packaging</FONT></B></P>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>&#147;WHEREAS:</FONT></B><FONT face=Arial size=2> A portion of Kroger house brand product packaging is unrecyclable,
including plastics, which are a growing component of marine litter. Authorities
say that marine litter kills and injures marine life, spreads toxics, and poses
a potential threat to human health.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>Plastic is the fastest growing form of
packaging; U.S. flexible plastic sales are estimated at $26 billion. Dried
fruit, frozen meat, cheese, and dog food are some of the Kroger house brand
items packaged in unrecyclable plastic pouches. Private label items account for
a quarter of all sales - nearly $20 billion annually. Using unrecyclable
packaging when recyclable alternatives are available wastes valuable resources.
William McDonough, a leading green design advisor, calls pouch packaging a
&#147;monstrous hybrid&#148; designed to end up either in a landfill or
incinerator.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>Recyclability of household packaging is a
growing area of focus as consumers become more environmentally conscious, yet
recycling rates stagnate. Only 14% of plastic packaging is recycled, according
to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Billions of pouches and
similar plastic laminates, representing significant embedded value, lie buried
in landfills. Unrecyclable packaging is more likely to be littered and swept
into waterways. A recent assessment of marine debris by a panel of the Global
Environment Facility concluded that one cause of debris entering oceans is
&#147;design and marketing of products internationally without appropriate regard to
their environmental fate or ability to be recycled...&#148;</FONT></P>

<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>In the marine
environment, plastics break down into indigestible particles that marine life
mistake for food. Studies by the EPA suggest a synergistic effect between
plastic debris and persistent, bio-accumulative, toxic chemicals. Plastics
absorb toxics such as polychlorinated biphenyls and dioxins from water or
sediment and transfer them to the marine food web and potentially to human
diets. One study of fish from the North Pacific found one or more plastic
chemicals in all fish tested, independent of location and species.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>California spends nearly $500 million
annually preventing trash, much of it packaging, from polluting beaches, rivers
and oceanfront. Making all packaging recyclable, if possible, is the first step
needed to reduce the threat posed by ocean debris.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>Companies who aspire to corporate
sustainability yet use these risky materials need to explain why they use
unrecyclable packaging. Other companies who manufacture and sell food and
household goods are moving towards recyclability. Procter &amp; Gamble and
Colgate-Palmolive agreed to make most of their packaging recyclable by 2020.
Keurig Green Mountain will make K-cup coffee pods recyclable; and McDonald&#146;s and
Dunkin Donuts shifted away from foam plastic cups, which cannot be readily
recycled. </FONT></P>

<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>RESOLVED:</FONT></B><FONT face=Arial size=2> Shareowners of Kroger request that the board of directors issue a
report, at reasonable cost, omitting confidential information, assessing the
environmental impacts of continuing to use unrecyclable brand
packaging.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Supporting Statement:</FONT></B><FONT face=Arial size=2> Proponents believe that the report should include an
assessment of the reputational, financial and operational risks associated with
continuing to use unrecyclable brand packaging and, if possible, goals and a
timeline to phase out unrecyclable packaging.&#148;</FONT></P>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>The Board of Directors Recommends a
Vote <U>Against</U> This Proposal for the Following Reasons:</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Kroger shares the proponent&#146;s concerns
regarding plastic recyclability and recognizes the important role we play as a
good steward of the environment.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>We continue to improve the recyclability
of our Corporate Brand products, while still preserving their safety and
quality. More specifically, we follow a balanced, multi-pronged approach to
optimizing packaging design that considers factors such as food safety, shelf
life, availability, quality, material type, function, recyclability and cost,
among others.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>We are increasingly labeling recyclable
Corporate Brand products per the Federal Trade Commission&#146;s Green Guides,
prompting our customers to &#147;PLEASE RECYCLE.&#148; One example is through our redesign
of Kroger brand milks, creams and orange juices that come in quart, pint and
</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial>59</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>half-pint packages. The packaging for
these products is comprised of a bottle made from #1 polyethylene terephthalate
(PETE), one of the most widely recycled plastics available, and a shrink sleeve.
While the shrink sleeve is also made from #1 PETE, these shrink sleeves may
interfere with the ability of the bottles to be segregated and recycled when a
recycling facility uses optical scanning technology. As a result, in order to
increase the number of Corporate Brand #1 PETE bottles that can be properly
recycled, we have added a tear perforation and the consumer message, &#147;REMOVE
LABEL TO RECYCLE BOTTLE,&#148; to the shrink labels.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>We recognize that creating lasting
sustainable consumption patterns requires a comprehensive approach and so we
also work with various industry experts and forums to advocate for expanded
recycling infrastructure to support both multiple forms of plastic packaging and
diversion from landfills.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Additionally, our banner brand bread bags
are made from low-density polyethylene (LDPE). This type of plastic can be a
contaminant in many single stream recycling programs. To help our customers
recycle their LDPE bread bags we have added customer communication on the bag
that reads, &#147;Please recycle at your local, Kroger Family of Stores drop-off
location.&#148; These drop-off recycling bins are part of our plastic bag recycling
program and are typically located in the front vestibule of our stores. Along
with bread bags, customers can also recycle clean and dry plastic bags, bottled
water case wraps, bathroom tissue and diaper plastic overwraps, dry cleaning
bags, and newspaper bags. This program is currently undergoing rebranding and
expansion to encourage customers to recycle even more in 2016 and
beyond.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>For each of the past several years we have
published online our annual Sustainability Report that highlights our
sustainability initiatives and waste reduction efforts in greater detail,
available at sustainability.kroger.com. In that report, we set forth a rigorous
and tangible goal to strive to have zero waste in our retail locations. Through
this initiative, and others, we will continue to support efforts to reduce
waste, find optimized solutions and advocate for expanded recycling
infrastructure as we believe these efforts are significant and meaningful. We
urge you to support these efforts and vote </FONT><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>AGAINST</FONT></B><FONT face=Arial size=2> this proposal.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Item No. 6 Shareholder
Proposal</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>We have been notified by two shareholders,
the names and shareholdings of which will be furnished promptly to any
shareholder upon written or oral request to Kroger&#146;s Secretary at our executive
offices, that they intend to propose the following resolution at the annual
meeting:</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Shareholder Proposal<BR>Renewable
Energy</FONT></B></P>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>&#147;Whereas:</FONT></B></P>
<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>To mitigate the worst impacts of climate
change, the United Nations has stated that global warming must not increase more
than 2 degrees Celsius beyond pre-industrial levels, which implies U.S. carbon
dioxide emission reductions of 80% from 1990 levels by 2050. (IPCC 2013). At the
2015 United Nations Conference of Parties in Paris, 195 parties agreed on a
pathway to achieve a 2 degree limit.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>At $108 billion in sales, Kroger is the
6th largest global retailer, and is 20th on Fortune&#146;s 2015 Fortune 500 list
(Kroger 10k; Deloitte, 2015; Fortune). Kroger&#146;s globally significant carbon
emissions - which exceed 29 nations&#146; respective carbon emissions from energy -
are not being adequately addressed. (Kroger, &#147;Energy/Carbon&#148; website; IEA,
Energy Atlas). Kroger lacks climate targets, and where many companies are
reducing carbon, Kroger&#146;s 2014 Scope 1 emissions increased from the previous
year. Despite its significant carbon footprint, Kroger has installed renewable
energy at only 8 of its 3,806 stores, plants, and distribution centers,
approximately 0.2% of its locations. (Kroger &#147;Energy/Carbon&#148; website,
Factbook).</FONT></P>
<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>In contrast, Whole Foods Market offsets
its entire power use with renewable energy credits, and Walmart is at 24%
renewable power. (Whole Foods, &#147;Green Mission&#148;; Walmart, &#147;Walmart&#146;s Approach to
Renewable Energy&#148;). Indeed, Whole Foods Market, Walmart, Whole Foods Market, and
other food companies including Coca-Cola Enterprises, Mars, Nestle, and
Starbucks have committed to working towards 100% renewable energy. (RE100).</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial>60</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>Investing in carbon reduction can benefit
Kroger&#146;s shareholder value. Carbon reduction activities can be lucrative,
yielding returns over 30%. (&#147;Lower emissions, higher ROI&#148;, Carbon Disclosure
Project, 2014). Research indicates that corporate management of climate impacts
can lead to improved financial performance, including enhanced return on equity,
stronger dividends, lower earnings volatility, and minimized regulatory risk.
(&#147;S&amp;P 500 Leaders Report&#148;, Carbon Disclosure Project, 2014)</FONT></P>

<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>According to
Eric Schmidt, Executive Chairman of Google (another RE100 signatory): &#147;Much of
corporate America is buying renewable energy [...] not just to be sustainable,
because it makes business sense, helping companies diversify their power supply,
hedge against fuel risks, and support innovation in an increasingly
cost-competitive way.&#148; (&#147;Google&#146;s commitment to sustainability&#148;, Google Green
Blog, 2014).</FONT></P>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Resolved:</FONT></B></P>
<P align=left><FONT face=Arial size=2>Shareholders request that Kroger produce a
report, by year end 2016, assessing the climate benefits and feasibility of
adopting enterprise-wide, quantitative, time bound targets for increasing
Kroger&#146;s renewable energy sourcing. The report should be produced at reasonable
cost and exclude proprietary information.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Supporting: </FONT></B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Shareholders request that the report include an analysis of options and
scenarios for achieving renewable energy targets, for example by using on-site
distributed energy, off-site generation, power purchases, and renewable energy
credits, or other opportunities management would like to consider, at its
discretion.&#148;</FONT></P>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>The Board of Directors Recommends a
Vote <U>Against</U> This Proposal for the Following Reasons:</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Kroger shares the proponents&#146; concerns
regarding renewable energy sourcing. We are committed to environmental
sustainability and we strive to reduce our impact on the environment by using
natural resources responsibly and minimizing waste in all of our
operations.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Our aggressive work in energy management
resulted in a reduction of overall energy consumption in our stores saving more
than 2.5 billion kWh since 2000. This is the carbon equivalent of taking 362,922
cars off the road for one year.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>We are actively working to do more in both
the short- and long-term. For example, our Turkey Hill Dairy has two wind energy
turbines with 3.2 megawatt capacity. Since 2011, these turbines have supplied up
to 25% of the dairy&#146;s annual electricity needs, which is enough power to produce
six million gallons of ice cream and 15 million gallons of iced tea. In
addition, ten Kroger stores have approximately 3,092kW of solar energy capacity
that in 2015 produced approximately 3.94 million kWh.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>The Kroger Recovery System, located in
Compton, CA at the Ralphs/Food 4 Less distribution center has been in operation
since late 2012. It utilizes anaerobic digestion, a naturally occurring process,
to transform food waste into renewable biogas. This system annually processes
approximately 45,000 tons of food waste. This biogas is then turned into power
for onsite operations. The system provided approximately 3.5 million kWh of
renewable energy for the 650,000 square foot Ralphs/Food 4 Less distribution
center. The system reduces area truck trips by more than 500,000 miles each year
and reduces waste costs. These efforts are estimated to reduce carbon emissions
by 90,000 tons per year.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>For each of the past several years, we
have published online our annual Sustainability Report that highlights our
sustainability initiatives and waste reduction efforts in greater detail. We
will continue to support efforts to increase our renewable energy sourcing as we
believe these efforts are significant and meaningful. You can view our
Sustainability Report at </FONT><I><FONT face=Arial size=2>sustainability.kroger.com</FONT></I><FONT face=Arial size=2> where we
address a number of the requests made by the proponent including quantitative
enterprise-wide renewable energy production metrics, and supply-chain management
through our logistics initiative.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>We remain committed to environmental
sustainability and renewable energy sourcing and we will continue to publish
reports to our shareholders tracking our initiatives. We urge you to support the
furthering of our current programs and vote</FONT><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>
AGAINST</FONT></B><FONT face=Arial size=2> this proposal.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial>61</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Item No. 7 Shareholder
Proposal</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>We have been notified by one shareholder,
the name and shareholdings of which will be furnished promptly to any
shareholder upon written or oral request to Kroger&#146;s Secretary at our executive
offices, that it intends to propose the following resolution at the annual
meeting:</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Shareholder Proposal<BR>Share
Repurchase vs. Dividend</FONT></B></P>
<P align=left><I><FONT face=Arial size=2>&#147;Resolved:</FONT></I><FONT face=Arial size=2> Shareholders of The Kroger Co. ask the board of directors to adopt and
issue a general payout policy that gives preference to share repurchases
(relative to cash dividends) as a method to return capital to shareholders. If a
general payout policy currently exists, we ask that it be amended
appropriately.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><I><FONT face=Arial size=2>Supporting statement:</FONT></I><FONT face=Arial size=2> Share repurchases as a method to return capital to
shareholders have distinct advantages relative to dividends. Share repurchases
should be preferred for the following reasons:</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face=Arial size=2>1)</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="100%"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Financial flexibility. Four
      professors from Duke University and Cornell University studied executives&#146;
      decisions to pay dividends or make repurchases by surveying hundreds of
      executives of public companies. They found that &#147;maintaining the dividend
      level is on par with investment decisions, while repurchases are made out
      of the residual cash flow after investment spending.&#148;<SUP>1
      </SUP></FONT><FONT face=Arial size=2>Further, in follow up interviews as
      part of the study, executives &#147;state[d] that they would pass up some
      positive net present value (NPV) investment projects before cutting
      dividends.&#148; The creation of long-term value is of paramount importance; I
      believe that repurchases have the distinct advantage that they do not
      create an incentive to forgo long-term value enhancing projects in order
      to preserve a historic dividend level.</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD noWrap></TD>
    <TD width="100%" colSpan=3>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR valign=top>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face=Arial size=2>2)</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap></TD>
    <TD width="100%"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Tax efficiency. Share repurchases
      have been described in the Wall Street Journal<SUP>2 </SUP></FONT><FONT face=Arial size=2>as &#147;akin to dividends, but without the tax bite for
      shareholders.&#148; The distribution of a dividend may automatically trigger a
      tax liability for some shareholders. The repurchase of shares does not
      necessarily trigger that automatic tax liability and therefore gives a
      shareholder the flexibility to choose when the tax liability is incurred.
      Shareholders who desire cash flow can choose to sell shares and pay taxes
      as appropriate. (This proposal does not constitute tax
  advice.)</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD noWrap></TD>
    <TD width="100%" colSpan=3>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face=Arial size=2>3)</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap></TD>
    <TD width="100%"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Market acceptance: Some may
      believe that slowing the growth rate or reducing the level of dividends
      would result in a negative stock market reaction. However, a study
      published in the Journal of Finance finds that the market response to
      cutting dividends by companies that were also share repurchasers was not
      statistically distinguishable from zero.<SUP>3 </SUP></FONT><FONT face=Arial size=2>I believe this study provides evidence that there is
      market acceptance that repurchases are valid substitutes for
      dividends.</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Some may worry that share repurchases
could be used to prop up metrics that factor into the compensation of
executives. I believe that any such concern should not interfere with the choice
of optimal payout mechanism because compensation packages can be designed such
that metrics are adjusted to account for share repurchases.</FONT></P>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>In summary, I strongly believe that
adopting a general payout policy that gives preference to share repurchases
would enhance long-term value creation. I urge shareholders to vote FOR this
proposal.&#148;</FONT></DIV><DIV>____________________</DIV><BR>
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 border=0>

  <TR>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face=Arial size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face=Arial size=2>1</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face=Arial size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="100%"><FONT face=Arial size=2>http://www.
      sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304405XO5000528</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD noWrap></TD>
    <TD width="100%" colSpan=3>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face=Arial size=2>2</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap></TD>
    <TD width="100%"><FONT face=Arial size=2>http://www.wsj.com/articles/companies-stock-buybacks-help-buoy-the-market-1410823441</FONT></TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD noWrap></TD>
    <TD width="100%" colSpan=3>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
  <TR>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap><FONT face=Arial size=2>3</FONT></TD>
    <TD vAlign=top noWrap></TD>
    <TD width="100%"><FONT face=Arial size=2>http://www.afajof.org/details/journalArticle/2893861/Dividends-Share-Repurchases-and-the-
      Substitution-Hypothesis.html</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial>62</FONT></B></P>
<HR align=center width="100%" noShade SIZE=2>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>The Board of Directors Recommends a
Vote <U>Against</U> This Proposal for the Following Reasons:</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Kroger believes that the policy advocated
by the shareholder proposal is not in the best interests of our shareholders as
it reduces long-term flexibility in the allocation of capital. In a rapidly
evolving capital market, this flexibility is an essential element in the careful
management of shareholder capital, which the Board thoughtfully oversees and
reviews on a regular basis.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Our long-term financial strategy continues
to be to use cash flow from operations, in a balanced manner, to repurchase
shares, fund dividends, and increase capital investments, all while maintaining
our current investment grade debt rating. Our balanced approach gives us the
flexibility to pursue long-term growth strategies while returning capital to our
shareholders.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Kroger is proud of our strong history of
capital return to shareholders. We have made significant commitments over time
to return capital to shareholders both through repurchases of our common shares
and payment of cash dividends. We repurchased $703 million of Kroger common
shares in 2015, as well as $1.1 billion in 2014, $338 million in 2013 and $1.2
billion in 2012. Additionally, we paid dividends totaling $385 million in 2015,
$338 million in 2014, $319 million in 2013 and $267 million in 2012. We are also
committed to growing long-term shareholder value through significant capital
investments. Excluding acquisitions, we invested $3.38 billion, $2.89 billion,
$2.46 billion and $2.06 billion in capital projects in 2015, 2014, 2013, and
2012, respectively. Many of our shareholders view both dividends and share
repurchases as an important component of Kroger&#146;s investment profile, especially
in light of our balanced capital return strategy that contributes to a healthy
TSR (total shareholder return), which outperforms both our peers and the S&amp;P
500 over time.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>When contemplating capital returns, the
Board engages in a thorough analysis and oversight process. Before the Board
approves any share repurchase program or declares a cash dividend, it takes into
account a wide range of factors, including Kroger&#146;s short and long-term growth
strategies, liquidity needs and capital requirements, cash flows, net earnings,
debt obligations, and leverage ratios. The Board also considers how the
then-current capital market conditions affect Kroger&#146;s policies and strategies.
There is no one-size-fits-all policy or strategy in returning capital to
shareholders that would satisfy each market condition over the course of time.
Balanced capital allocation decisions, overseen by an effective Board, remain
the most effective and flexible strategy to continuously deliver healthy value
to shareholders over the long-term.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>This proposal requests that Kroger adopt a
general policy that gives preference to share repurchases relative to cash
dividends. We urge you to vote </FONT><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>AGAINST</FONT></B><FONT face=Arial size=2> this proposal.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial>63</FONT></B></P>


<HR align=center width="100%" noshade SIZE=2>
<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<!-- H -->
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Shareholder Proposals and Director
Nominations &#150; 2017 Annual Meeting</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Shareholder proposals intended for
inclusion in the proxy material relating to Kroger&#146;s annual meeting of
shareholders in June 2017 should be addressed to Kroger&#146;s Secretary and must be
received at our executive offices not later than January 12, 2017. These
proposals must comply with Rule 14a-8 and the SEC&#146;s proxy rules.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>In addition, Kroger&#146;s Regulations contain
an advance notice of shareholder business and director nominations requirement,
which generally prescribes the procedures that a shareholder of Kroger must
follow if the shareholder intends, at an annual meeting, to nominate a person
for election to Kroger&#146;s Board of Directors or to propose other business to be
considered by shareholders. These procedures include, among other things, that
the shareholder give timely notice to Kroger&#146;s Secretary of the nomination or
other proposed business, that the notice contain specified information, and that
the shareholder comply with certain other requirements. In order to be timely,
this notice must be delivered in writing to Kroger&#146;s Secretary, at our principal
executive offices, not later 45 calendar days prior to the date on which our
proxy statement for the prior year&#146;s annual meeting of shareholders was mailed
to shareholders. If a shareholder&#146;s nomination or proposal is not in compliance
with the procedures set forth in the Regulations, we may disregard such
nomination or proposal. Accordingly, if a shareholder intends, at the 2017
annual meeting, to nominate a person for election to the Board of Directors or
to propose other business, the shareholder must deliver a notice of such
nomination or proposal to Kroger&#146;s Secretary not later March 28, 2017, and
comply with the requirements of the Regulations. If a shareholder submits a
proposal outside of Rule 14a-8 for the 2017 annual meeting and such proposal is
not delivered within the time frame specified in the Regulations, Kroger&#146;s proxy
may confer discretionary authority on persons being appointed as proxies on
behalf of Kroger to vote on such proposal. Shareholder proposals, director
nominations and advance notices should be addressed in writing to: Secretary,
The Kroger Co., 1014 Vine Street, Cincinnati, Ohio 45202-1100.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>2015 Annual Report</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Attached to this Proxy Statement is our
2015 Annual Report which includes a brief description of our business, including
the general scope and nature thereof during fiscal year 2015, together with the
audited financial information contained in our 2015 Annual Report on Form 10-K
filed with the SEC. </FONT><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>A copy of that report is
available to shareholders on request without charge by writing to: Todd A.
Foley, Treasurer, The Kroger Co., 1014 Vine Street, Cincinnati, Ohio 45202-1100
or by calling 513-762-1220</FONT></B><FONT face=Arial size=2>. Our SEC filings
are available to the public on the SEC&#146;s website at www.sec.gov.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Householding of Proxy
Materials</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>We have adopted a procedure approved by
the SEC called &#147;householding.&#148; Under this procedure, shareholders of record who
have the same address and last name will receive only one copy of the Notice of
Availability of Proxy Materials (or proxy materials in the case of shareholders
who receive paper copies of such materials) unless one or more of these
shareholders notifies us that they wish to continue receiving individual copies.
This procedure will reduce our printing costs and postage fees. Householding
will not in any way affect dividend check mailings.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>If you are eligible for householding, but
you and other shareholders of record with whom you share an address currently
receive multiple copies of our Notice of Availability of Proxy Materials (or
proxy materials in the case of shareholders who receive paper copies of such
materials), or if you hold in more than one account, and in either case you wish
to receive only a single copy for your household or if you prefer to receive
separate copies of our documents in the future, please contact your bank or
broker, or contact Kroger&#146;s Secretary at 1014 Vine Street, Cincinnati, Ohio
45202-1100 or via telephone at 513-762-4000.</FONT></P>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Beneficial shareholders can request
information about householding from their banks, brokers or other holders of
record.</FONT></DIV>
<DIV align=center>____________________</DIV>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>The management knows of no other matters
that are to be presented at the meeting, but, if any should be presented, the
Proxy Committee expects to vote thereon according to its best
judgment.</FONT></P>

<DIV style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always"></DIV><BR>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>FINANCIAL REPORT 2015</FONT></B></P>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>MANAGEMENT&#146;S RESPONSIBILITY FOR
FINANCIAL REPORTING</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>The management of The Kroger Co. has the
responsibility for preparing the accompanying financial statements and for their
integrity and objectivity. The statements were prepared in accordance with
generally accepted accounting principles applied on a consistent basis and are
not misstated due to material error or fraud. The financial statements include
amounts that are based on management&#146;s best estimates and judgments. Management
also prepared the other information in the report and is responsible for its
accuracy and consistency with the financial statements.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Kroger&#146;s financial statements have been
audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public
accounting firm, whose selection has been ratified by the shareholders.
Management has made available to PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP all of Kroger&#146;s
financial records and related data, as well as the minutes of the shareholders&#146;
and directors&#146; meetings. Furthermore, management believes that all
representations made to PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP during its audit were valid
and appropriate.</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Management also recognizes its
responsibility for fostering a strong ethical climate so that Kroger&#146;s affairs
are conducted according to the highest standards of personal and corporate
conduct. This responsibility is characterized and reflected in </FONT><I><FONT face=Arial size=2>The Kroger Co. Policy on Business Ethics</FONT></I><FONT face=Arial size=2>, which is publicized throughout Kroger and available on
Kroger&#146;s website at ir.kroger.com. </FONT><I><FONT face=Arial size=2>The Kroger
Co. Policy on Business Ethics</FONT></I><FONT face=Arial size=2> addresses,
among other things, the necessity of ensuring open communication within Kroger;
potential conflicts of interests; compliance with all domestic and foreign laws,
including those related to financial disclosure; and the confidentiality of
proprietary information. Kroger maintains a systematic program to assess
compliance with these policies.</FONT></P>
<P align=left><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>MANAGEMENT&#146;S REPORT ON INTERNAL CONTROL
OVER FINANCIAL REPORTING</FONT></B></P>
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>Management is responsible for establishing
and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting for the
Company. With the participation of the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief
Financial Officer, our management conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness
of our internal control over financial reporting based on the framework and
criteria established in </FONT><I><FONT face=Arial size=2>Internal Control &#150;
Integrated Framework (2013)</FONT></I><FONT face=Arial size=2>, issued by the
Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission. Our management
excluded Roundy&#146;s, Inc. from its assessment of internal control over financial
reporting because it was acquired in a purchase business combination on December
18, 2015. Roundy&#146;s, Inc. is a wholly-owned subsidiary whose total assets and
total revenues represent 2% and less than 1%, respectively, of the related
consolidated financial statement amounts as of and for the year ended January
30, 2016. Based on this evaluation, management has concluded that the Company&#146;s
internal control over financial reporting was effective as of January 30,
2016.</FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="text-indent: 15pt"><FONT face=Arial size=2>During 2015, we paid two quarterly cash
dividends of $0.0925 per share and two quarterly cash dividends of $0.105 per
share. During 2014, we paid three quarterly cash dividends of $0.0825 per share
and one quarterly cash dividend of $0.0925 per share. On March 1, 2016, we paid
a quarterly cash dividend of $0.105 per share. On March 10, 2016, we announced
that our Board of Directors have declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.105
per share, payable on June 1, 2016, to shareholders of record at the close of
business on May 13, 2016. We currently expect to continue to pay comparable cash
dividends on a quarterly basis depending on our earnings and other
factors.</FONT></P>
<P align=center><B><FONT face=Arial>A-2</FONT></B></P>

with the cumulative total return of companies in the Standard &amp; Poor&#146;s 500
Stock Index and a peer group composed of food and drug companies.</FONT></P>

      of</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Shares</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Purchased</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>as</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Part
      of</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Publicly</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Announced</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Plans
      or<BR></FONT></B>Programs <SUP>(3)</SUP></FONT></STRONG></TD>
    <TD NOWRAP STYLE="padding-bottom: 2pt; width: 1%; text-align: center; width: 1%; padding-top: 2pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD NOWRAP STYLE="padding-bottom: 2pt; width: 1%; border-bottom: #000000 1pt solid; text-align: center; width: 1%; padding-top: 2pt"><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Maximum<BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Dollar</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Value
      of</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Shares</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>that May Yet</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Be</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Purchased</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Under</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>the Plans
      or</FONT></B><BR><B><FONT face=Arial size=2>Programs </FONT></B><B><FONT face=Arial size=2><SUP>(4)<BR></SUP></FONT></B>(in
  millions)</FONT></B></TD></TR>
  <TR vAlign=bottom>
    <TD noWrap align=left width="85%" bgColor=#c0c0c0><FONT face=Arial size=2>First period - four weeks</FONT></TD>
